ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: All things 3D: lines and planes, vector valued functions, vector projection, partial derivatives, chain rule, directional derivatives, tangent planes, contour maps, vector fields, finding extrema, Lagrange multipliers, double integrals, line integrals, parametric surfaces, surface integrals, triple integrals in rectangular/cylindrical/spherical coordinates. I learned so much this semester!
I have gained valuable insight on the application of calculus in three dimensions.
Multivariable calculus! I feel like we covered lots of fun material at a steady pace.
I've gained understanding of multivariable calculus which serves as the basis for further study of mathematics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The pre-class videos were an absolute gem in terms of learning the material. The practice exams and review sessions were very helpful. And the peer tutors and teachers made themselves very available to help. Unfortunately, I found that the teaching in class was lacking.

One strength was the peer tutors. They were always so helpful and kind. I thought a weakness was some of the course wide review sessions before the midterms and final. While about half of them were very helpful (in general the ones taught by professors), there were a few where I thought the information was presented very unclearly.

This course is very fast-paced, and that would be fine if there were better teachers but since the majority of sections are taught by grad students, the experience varies and really just depends on whether or not you are lucky enough to get into John or Miki's sections. The grad students are incredibly smart but ultimately fail to communicate/translate their brilliance to the level of those who are learning multivariable for the first time. As a result, i often found myself go out of my way to teach myself with the resources provided by the course and outside resources. However, that ultimately meant class was virtually a waste of time.

Strengths: Reasonably paced, provided with lots of resources/additional help
Improvements: The order of the materials taught at the end of the semester did not follow the textbook, which made learning some lessons a little confusing

The design of the course is nice. Students are required to study required topics based on pre-uploaded videos before each class and the class is for answering questions that students couldn't understanding after the self-study. This is a very effective use of class time because attention could be put on more difficult topics rather than spread across the entire syllabus. Generally, all our doubts and concerns could be answered in class.
The weekly problem set is also a good and necessary measure to make students practice enough and get used to complicated mathematical concepts as soon as possible. I wouldn't have been able to master what this course covered without the practice offered by the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! If you enjoyed calc AB/BC in high school, you'll probably enjoy this class too. I loved how calc 3 built on the topics we learned in calc 1/2 in cool, interesting ways. If math is really not your thing, I don't recommend this class.
I think if someone likes math this would be a good course to take. However, if you are not passionate about math, I don't think it would be enjoyable at all.
I honestly would not recommend this course for leisure. Since it is an integral prerequisite for certain majors, I know it's necessary. But if you don't have to take it, I would not recommend it.
I would especially recommend this course to another student if they are a prospective STEM major; I would still recommend this course to students who are interested in higher dimension calculus.
Absolutely. Everyone needs to know multivariable calculus.

Yes! It is a very clear and formulaic and organized course. It's a course that would never blindside you, which I personally appreciated it. The psets and exams are very doable if you go to class or watch the videos. And the workload is generally even throughout the semester.
I would. This course is the foundation for further mathematical studies and is necessary for many other subject areas.
